results.headline: With a Dentist’s Chair and a Chicken Mask, a Girl Can’t Say No
results.summary_short: “About Last Night,” a raucously entertaining remake, follows the difficulties faced by two couples, one sensitive and well behaved, the other outrageously naughty.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of About Last Night

results.headline: Romance and Tourism
results.summary_short: “Girl on a Bicycle,” a comedy set in Paris, centers on a tour bus driver who is entranced by a passing cyclist.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Girl on a Bicycle

results.headline: Hellbent on Fusing His Soul With Hers
results.summary_short: “Endless Love, based on the 1979 novel by Scott Spencer, focuses on an all-consuming relationship between a boy and a privileged girl whose parents are deeply concerned about it.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Endless Love

results.headline: Dates Blind and Less So in a Starry Metropolis
results.summary_short: “Beijing Love Story,” adapted from a Chinese TV series, offers a string of romantic tales set in a throbbing urban landscape.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beijing Love Story

results.headline: Take My Bro, Please
results.summary_short: In “Someone Marry Barry,” three friends of the title character, an affable shlub, try to find him a wife.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Someone Marry Barry

results.headline: Less Redemption, More Tears
results.summary_short: An ordinary man gets a new life in “RoboCop,” directed by José Padilha.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of RoboCop

results.headline: Exploring Black Americans’ Opinions of Same-Sex Marriage
results.summary_short: Yoruba Richen explores African-American attitudes toward same-sex marriage in “The New Black,” which opens at Film Forum on Wednesday.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The New Black

results.headline: Bloody Trouble at School
results.summary_short: “Vampire Academy,” based on Richelle Mead’s young adult series, uses many familiar themes of the bloodsucking genre.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vampire Academy

results.headline: But You Can’t Deny Destiny
results.summary_short: In “Hasee Toh Phasee,” a wedding is approaching, but the groom has some things on his mind, including his fiancée’s long-estranged sister.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hasee Toh Phasee

results.headline: After a Bad Breakup, Anything Goes
results.summary_short: “Love & Air Sex,” which follows two couples whose relationships have recently dissolved, is set in a city teeming with singles and air sex competitions.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love & Air Sex

results.headline: Eichmann’s Rabbi Gazes Backward
results.summary_short: Claude Lanzmann’s latest film, “The Last of the Unjust,” focuses on Benjamin Murmelstein but is a more personal film than Mr. Lanzmann’s previous works.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last of the Unjust

results.headline: A Jumbled Journey Through a Curious Marketplace
results.summary_short: A pushcart delivery boy in Paraguay takes a job for a shady butcher, and chaos ensues in this film directed by Juan Carlos Maneglia and Tana Schémbori.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 7 Boxes

results.headline: Now They’ll Love Me, a Twin Sister Schemes
results.summary_short: “The Pretty One” stars Zoe Kazan as a pair of twins, one mousy and insecure, the other vivacious. When the popular twin dies in a car accident, her sister decides to assume her identity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pretty One

results.headline: There Can Be Frightening Things in the Canadian Woods
results.summary_short: “Vic + Flo Saw a Bear,” starring Pierrette Robitaille and Romane Bohringer, starts with eccentric humor and ends as a scary tale of revenge.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vic+Flo Saw a Bear

results.headline: Toying With Ideas Outside the Manual
results.summary_short: “The Lego Movie” flirts with flouting its marketing imperative even as it embodies it.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lego Movie

results.headline: Mad Daddy on a Mission
results.summary_short: In “The Outsider,” a British mercenary visits Los Angeles to investigate his daughter’s apparent death.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Outsider

results.headline: They’re Single, and Creeps. The Women, Too.
results.summary_short: Skylar Astin, who plays a smart, funny young man searching for love in TV’s “Ground Floor,” is a bland, morose version of that character in “Cavemen.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cavemen

results.headline: Why, Yes, This Is Going to Hurt
results.summary_short: “Nurse 3D” tells the tale of a vengeful, scantily clad member of the profession, played by Paz de la Huerta, and the men she murders.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nurse 3D

results.headline: Dreamscapes of a Nightmarish Conflict
results.summary_short: Jessica Habie’s “Mars at Sunrise” distills the Israeli-Palestinian conflict to a single duel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mars at Sunrise

results.headline: A Play for Justice in South Korea
results.summary_short: “The Attorney” is based on a notorious 1981 case of government oppression and has been a blockbuster in South Korea.
